security_audit.summary: The skill contains multiple critical command injection vulnerabilities due to unsanitized user input in shell commands. While the functionality is legitimate for release management, immediate security fixes are required before production use.

critical_findings.title: Command Injection in Dynamic Shell Commands
critical_findings.description: Multiple instances of unsanitized variables being interpolated directly into shell commands. For example: `gh api repos/:owner/:repo/compare/${LAST_TAG}...HEAD` where LAST_TAG could contain malicious commands. An attacker controlling tag names could execute arbitrary code.

critical_findings.title: Path Traversal in File Operations
critical_findings.description: File write operations use unsanitized paths. The Write() function calls accept dynamic paths without validation, allowing path traversal attacks like writing to ../../../etc/passwd.

high_findings.title: Dynamic Docker Operations
high_findings.description: Docker commands use dynamic image names and volume mounts without validation. Commands like `docker build -t ${{ github.repository }}:${{ github.ref_name }}` could be exploited with malicious image names.

high_findings.title: Unvalidated GitHub API Parameters
high_findings.description: GitHub API calls use dynamic parameters without validation. API endpoints constructed with variables could lead to SSRF attacks or API abuse.

medium_findings.title: Credential Exposure in Commands
medium_findings.description: GitHub tokens and npm tokens are passed through shell commands which could be logged or exposed. Example: `echo '${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}' | gh auth login --with-token`

medium_findings.title: Dynamic Git Reference Generation
medium_findings.description: Git references like branches and tags are generated dynamically without validation. Could allow reference injection attacks.

dangerous_patterns.title: Command Substitution in User Input
dangerous_patterns.description: Using command substitution with user-controlled data: `$(gh api repos/:owner/:repo/git/refs/heads/main --jq '.object.sha')` could execute arbitrary commands if input is compromised.

dangerous_patterns.title: Temporary File Race Conditions
dangerous_patterns.description: Using predictable temp file paths in /tmp without proper security controls could lead to symlink attacks or information disclosure.

content.user_title: Automate GitHub Releases with AI Swarm Coordination
content.value_statement: Managing software releases involves multiple complex steps that often lead to errors and delays. This skill orchestrates your entire release pipeline using AI agents that handle versioning, testing, deployment, and monitoring automatically.
actual_capabilities: Orchestrates multi-agent release workflows with 6 specialized AI agents
Automates semantic versioning based on commit analysis and breaking changes
Coordinates cross-platform builds for npm, Docker, and binary artifacts
Implements progressive deployment with automated rollback triggers
Generates categorized changelogs with migration guides
Monitors release health with real-time metrics and alerts
limitations: Requires GitHub CLI and proper repository permissions
Security vulnerabilities present - input validation needed
Advanced features need claude-flow and swarm coordination setup
Performance depends on project size and test suite complexity

use_cases.title: Automated Release Pipeline
use_cases.description: Set up complete CI/CD release workflows that handle versioning, testing, and deployment across multiple platforms automatically.

use_cases.title: Multi-Package Coordination
use_cases.description: Coordinate releases across multiple repositories with dependency validation and synchronized versioning.

use_cases.title: Staged Production Rollouts
use_cases.description: Implement canary deployments with automated health monitoring and instant rollback capabilities for critical systems.

best_practices: Always validate and sanitize version strings, branch names, and user inputs before using in commands
Use allowlists for deployment targets and limit file system access to specific directories
Implement proper credential management with secure token storage and rotation
anti_patterns: Never interpolate user input directly into shell commands without validation
Avoid using dynamic file paths without path traversal protection
Do not expose credentials in command logs or process output

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with private GitHub repositories?
faq.answer: Yes, it works with both public and private repositories when authenticated with appropriate GitHub tokens.

faq.question: What are the rate limits for GitHub API calls?
faq.answer: The skill respects GitHub's rate limits of 5000 requests per hour for authenticated users, with automatic retry and backoff.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my existing CI/CD pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill provides GitHub Actions workflows and can be integrated with Jenkins, GitLab CI, or other systems.

faq.question: How does the skill handle data safety and security?
faq.answer: Currently the skill has security vulnerabilities. Use only in controlled environments until input validation is implemented.

faq.question: What should I do if a release fails during deployment?
faq.answer: The skill includes automated rollback capabilities that trigger based on error rates, latency, or availability thresholds.

faq.question: How does this compare to traditional release tools?
faq.answer: Unlike manual tools, this uses AI swarm coordination for parallel execution and intelligent decision-making during releases.
